overview_of_class:
A key portion of this course is focused on documentary cinematography, lighting and sound. Using the Canon C100 camera, students will learn the technical and aesthetic challenges and opportunities of shooting non-fiction. A second portion of the course will center on the basic theoretical, organizational, and practical aspects of editing documentary - using Adobe Premiere Pro CC. By the end of the course, students will have a practical grasp of shooting and editing workflows using these technologies and will be able to communicate in the language of cinematography.

The exercises in RTVF 479 will build practical skills while also allowing for aesthetic exploration.
We'll start with the basics, including three-point lighting and interview audio, then progress into observational shooting and other techniques.

Class time will include discussion of filmmaking techniques, screening films, and in-class exercises. A portion of class time will also be dedicated to helping students consider the opportunities and constraints of a two-year MFA media production degree - and how to make the most of that experience. As time allows, we will also spend time helping students develop aesthetic approaches to their first-quarter films.

overview_of_class: In this course you will become intimately familiar with the two HD cameras and their particular post-workflows: the RED One camera and Canon C-500. We'll explore lighting setups and exposure evaluation techniques that extend your knowledge from 380 into HD video, using all the digital exposure methods that both cameras feature. You'll become familiar with the software associated with each camera: RED Cine-X and Canon Raw Development Software, and how to incorporate them into Premiere. We'll do basic color grading in Premiere with the Lumetri plug-in (the scope of the class won't allow working with DaVinci Resolve). We will also explore some basics in green screen work and two-camera shooting.
